title: Toyah Cordingley's friends share heartbreaking messages about the family's ongoing struggle
text:
A grieving loved one of Toyah Cordingley has opened up about the struggle to heal from the 24-year-old's mysterious murder.

Family friend Wayne 'Prong' Trimble revealed the stages of 'disbelief', 'horror' and 'anger' he went through after the young woman was murdered on Wangetti Beach.

'Why did it happen? Why did it have to happen? Why is there some maniac like that loose?' he said.

'There's been a lot of murders and a lot of cruel things happen here, but this is top of the shelf.'

Mr Trimble and sculptor Cameron Donnachie began constructing Ms Cordingley a permanent memorial at the beach on Sunday.

A grieving loved one of Toyah Cordingley (pictured) has opened up about the struggle to heal from the 24-year-old's mysterious murder

The final design of the memorial will be completed in time for an official ceremony on Saturday - two days before the anniversary of her death on October 21, 2018.

Mr Donnachie filmed Mr Trimble and himself during the construction of the site, which included small stones spelling 'Toyah'.

A concrete slab was made for her memorial stone to go on, along with a large flat stone for visitors to sit on.

'It's been a bit of a busy old day for us today,' he said.

He noted how the site could be seen by cars driving on the highway, allowing them to see Toyah's memorial as they pass.

Mr Trimble and sculptor Cameron Donnachie have begun constructing her permanent memorial at the beach on Sunday

'I'm sure everyone who loved or knew Toyah will appreciate what we've done here for her and her family,' Mr Donnachie said.

The ceremony will see Smithfield State High School students singing Amazing Grace, followed by a minute's silence.

At least 250 daisies will be laid on the beach.
